column1: huffingtonpost 139870964782 "2016-02-23 22:00:23 GMT" http://huffingtonpost.tumblr.com/post/139870964782/28-queens-of-black-history-who-deserve-much-more "ghettablasta:  Let‚Äôs not forget about these trailblazing women this Black History Month.   Shirley Chisolm (1924‚Äì2005)     Chisolm broke major barriers when she became the first black congresswoman in 1968. She continued on her political track when she ran for president four years later
column2: making her the first major-party black candidate to run.     Claudette Colvin (1939-)     Several months before Rosa Parks‚Äô refusal to give up her seat on a bus
column3: Colvin was the FIRST person arrested for resisting bus segregation in Montgomery
column5: at the age of 15.     Septima Poinsette Clark (1898‚Äì1987)¬†   Clark was an educator and civil rights activist who established citizenship schools that helped many African Americans register to vote. Regarded as a pioneer in grassroots citizenship education
column6: she was active with the NAACP in getting more black teachers hired in the South.     Mary Church Terrell (1863‚Äì1954)     This women‚Äôs suffrage activist and journalist was the first president of the National Association of Colored Women and a charter member of the NAACP. She was also one of the first African American women to be awarded a college degree.      Angela Davis (1944-)     Davis is an American revolutionary and educator. The former Black Panther has fought for race
column7: class and gender equality over the years.      Ida B. Wells-Barnett (1862-1931)     Wells helped bring international attention to the horrors of lynching in the South with her investigative journalism. She was also elected as the Secretary of the Colored Press Association in 1889.     Kathleen Cleaver (1945-)     Kathleen Cleaver is one of the central figures in Black Panther history. She was the first communications secretary for the organization and is currently a law professor at Emory University. She also helped found the Human Rights Research Fund.     Dr. Dorothy Height (1912-2010)     Dr. Height was regarded by President Barack Obama as ‚Äúthe godmother of the Civil Rights Movement.‚Äù She served as the president of the National Council of Negro Women for over two decades and was instrumental in the integration of all YWCA centers in 1946. ¬†   Phillis Wheatley (1753-1784)      Wheatley was a former slave who was kidnapped from West Africa and brought to America. She was bought by a Boston family and became their personal servant. With the aid of the family
column8: she learned to read and eventually became one of the first women to publish a book of poetry in 1773.     Audre Lorde (1934-1992)     This Caribbean-American writer and activist was a self-described ‚Äúblack
column11: warrior and poet.‚Äù She empowered her readers with her moving poetry often tackling the injustices of racism
column12: sexism and homophobia. She‚Äôs known for her poetry and memoirs such as
column13: From a Land Where Other People Live
column14: The Black Unicorn and A Burst of Light.     Flo Kennedy (1916-2000)     Kennedy was a founding member of the National Organization of Women and one of the first black female lawyers to graduate from Columbia Law School.   Marsha P. Johnson (1945-1992)   Johnson was an outspoken and fearless trans woman who was a vital part in the fight for civil rights for the LGBT community in New York. She was known as the patron at Stonewall Inn who initiated resistance on the night the police raided the bar.   Sojourner Truth (1797-1883)     Born Isabella Baumfree
column15: she escaped slavery with her infant daughter and changed her name to Sojourner Truth. She‚Äôs best known for her speech delivered at the Ohio Women‚Äôs Rights Convention in 1851 titled ‚ÄúAin‚Äôt I A Woman?‚Äù     Fannie Lou Hamer (1917-1977)     Hamer was a civil rights activist and organizer of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee Fannie Lou Hamer¬†   Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune (1875-1955)     Dr. Bethune was an educator and civil rights activist who believed education was the key to racial advancement. She served as the president of the National Association of Colored Women and founded the National Council of Negro Women.   Gwendolyn Brooks (1917-2000)     This poet was the first African American to win a Pulitzer Prize for her 1949 book titled Annie Allen.     Bessie Coleman (1892-1926)     Coleman became the first black woman to earn a pilot‚Äôs license and the first black woman to stage a public flight in the United States     Lena Horne (1917-2010)     Horne was a popular actress and singer who was most known for her performances in the films ‚ÄúStormy Weather‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Wiz.‚Äù She worked closely with civil rights groups and refused to play roles that stereotyped black women. ¬†     Wilma Rudolph (1940-1994)     Nicknamed ‚Äúthe black gazelle
column16: ‚Äù Rudolph was born premature and was stricken with polio as a child. Though her doctor said she would never be able to walk without her brace
column17: she went on to become a track star. She became the first American woman to win three gold medals at a single Olympics in 1960.     Billie Holiday (1915-1959)     Holiday was an extremely influential jazz vocalist who was known for her ‚Äúdistinctive phrasing and expressive
column18: sometimes melancholy voice.‚Äù Two of her most famous songs are ‚ÄúGod Bless the Child‚Äù and ‚ÄúStrange Fruit
column19: ‚Äù a heart-wrenching ballad about blacks being lynched in the South.     Diane Nash (1938-)     Nash is a founding member of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee. She was instrumental in organizing the Freedom Rides
column20: which helped desegregate interstate buses in the South.      Zora Neale Hurston (1891-1960)     Hurston was an anthropologist and author during the Harlem Renaissance. Though she didn‚Äôt receive much recognition for her work while she was alive
column22: especially Their Eyes Were Watching God
column23: became staples in American literature.      Hattie McDaniel (1893-1952) ¬†   As an actress
column24: McDaniel appeared in more than 300 films and was the first African American to win an Oscar in 1940. She was also the star of the CBS Radio program
column25: ‚ÄúThe Beulah Show.‚Äù      Ruby Bridges (1954-)     Ruby Bridges was six years old when she became the first black child to integrate an all-white school in the South. She was escorted to class by her mother and U.S. marshals due to violent mobs outside of the Mississippi school.      Charlayne Hunter-Gault (1942-)     Hunter-Gault was the first black woman to enroll at the University of Georgia. She became an award-winning journalist after she graduated and worked for outlets such as the New York Times
column26: PBS and NPR.     Daisy Bates (1914-1999)     As a civil rights activist and journalist
column27: Bates documented the fight to end segregation in Arkansas. Along with her husband
column28: she ran a weekly black newspaper and became the president of the Arkansas chapter of the NAACP.   Dr. Mae Jemison (1956-)   ¬†   Dr. Jemison is the first black woman to be admitted into the astronaut training program and fly into space in 1987. Jemison also developed and participated in research projects on the Hepatitis B vaccine and rabies.       Ella Baker (1903-1986)     Baker was the national director for the ¬†NAACP. She also worked with the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee. As one of the leading figures in the civil rights movement
column29: Baker is known for her leadership style which helped develop others‚Äô skills to become leaders in the fight for a better future.    Let‚Äôs not forget about these trailblazing women this Black History Month. source Huffington Post " False text

column3: loving and present‚Ä¶ somehow people fail to realize this exists
column4: ‚Äù photographer Zun Lee told The Huffington Post. ‚ÄúSeeing black people just being is a powerful act.‚Äù Too many archetypes of black fathers in the media portray these men as aggressive and absent. To combat these notions
column5: Lee focuses his work on the various complexities of black fatherhood. Over the last four years
column8: all of them based on black fatherhood. His work features some of the most intimate images of fatherhood that
column10: send a strong message that pushes back against the negative assumptions about black fathers. ‚ÄúBlack people are expected to be supernatural and it‚Äôs a dangerous narrative and I‚Äôm rebelling against that. For us to be respectable
column12: ‚Äù Lee said. ‚ÄúMany men fall through the cracks. Many of these men aren‚Äôt married or live at home but these very men negotiate the notion of presence in a very meaningful way.‚Äù Lee
column13: a biracial man who had a rocky relationship with his own father
column14: grew up around black men who helped discipline and raise him as a child
column16: these men became father figures and inspired him to continue creating work that challenges the portrayal of fatherhood in a very fluid and realistic way. ‚ÄúBlack fathers are no different than other fathers
column17: ‚Äù Lee said. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need to owe an explanation or say that we deserve better treatment
column18: we are not criminal. We don‚Äôt have to prove anything to anyone. We are human. We‚Äôre not on trial here.‚Äù Whether his work captures a father‚Äôs long
column20: or their hands clasped to symbolize protection and presence
column21: Lee‚Äôs focus on these specific moments of love and affection is what makes his imagery so relatable. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not here to refute
column23: ‚Äù Lee said. ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt get it
column24: it‚Äôs fine. And when people demand an explanation
column25: that‚Äôs not for me to give.‚Äù  Read More: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/06/21/black-fatherhood-zun-lee_n_7631192.html Related Article: The Huffington Post by huffingtonpost - Tumblr " False text

column1: huffingtonpost 137222577374 "2016-01-13 15:30:07 GMT" http://huffingtonpost.tumblr.com/post/137222577374/betthearm-nearly-headless-horseman "betthearm:  nearly-headless-horseman:  aggressivelybicaptainamerica:  Finn is literally the most overt fuck you to toxic masculinity.¬† Like
column2: here‚Äôs a soldier who‚Äôs literally known nothing else but his warrior training his whole life
column3: who‚Äôs identity has been consumed to the point where he literally has a number instead of a name
column4: seeing what‚Äôs expected of him and rejecting it utterly. ¬†He‚Äôs obviously physically strong and capable
column5: but he finds his humanity in NOT using his strength
column6: and his heroism in finding a reason to use his strength.¬† He‚Äôs afraid for most of the movie
column7: conflicted and hesitant and still able to be brave and strong. ¬†In fact
column8: his truest moments of bravery are also the ones where he is the most afraid and uncertain. ¬†And his fear is never shamed or set up as a weakness
column9: but rather as a huge part of what makes him both human and heroic. It‚Äôs so important to me to see men allowed to feel a full range of emotions including fear and doubt and sadness and still be seen as strong and valuable. (I think there is an extra layer to this given that Finn is also a black man
column10: but I‚Äôm going to stay in my lane and let PoC tackle that.)  as a POC lemme say that finn is extra wonderful because even when he‚Äôs fighting
column11: he never looks scary. there‚Äôs always this theme that shows strong black men as intimidating and capable of harm but finn is the opposite of intimidating and from the very start you see that he doesnt want to hurt anyone and his strength is not associated with violence but with the ability to help others and he‚Äôs sweet and funny and real and no one would ever be afraid of him and both of the poc male leads are shown as caring and using their strength to protect and you‚Äôd never be afraid of either of them and there is no macho bullshit at all and it makes me so happy   But he does it anyway.¬† " False text

column2: but a state law may put some of the tax money directly into residents‚Äô pockets
column3: causing quite a headache for lawmakers.The state constitution limits how much tax money the state can take in before it has to give some back. That means Coloradans may each get their own cut of the $50 million in recreational pot taxes collected in the first year of legal weed. It‚Äôs a situation so bizarre that it‚Äôs gotten Republicans and Democrats
column5: to agree on a tax issue.Even some pot shoppers are surprised Colorado may not keep the taxes that were promised to go toward school construction when voters legalized marijuana in 2012. Read on here.¬†" True link

column1: huffingtonpost 109599001727 "2015-01-30 19:15:20 GMT" http://huffingtonpost.tumblr.com/post/109599001727/does-your-member-of-congress-offer-paid-maternity "huffpostpolitics:Continuing a push that began with the president‚Äôs State of the Union address
column2: Democratic members of Congress put forth a bill earlier this week that would extend six weeks of paid leave to federal workers after the birth of a child. The legislation would guarantee maternity and paternity leave with pay not just for employees at federal agencies
column3: but also for staffers inside the halls of Congress.Though it may surprise many Americans
column4: each congressional office currently acts as its own fiefdom when it comes to paid leave for employees. The Family and Medical Leave Act guarantees congressional staffers 12 weeks of unpaid leave with a new child
column5: but the members themselves get to decide how much paid time off their staffers receive. The generosity inevitably varies from office to office. After the State of the Union address
column6: The Huffington Post began asking lawmakers for their offices‚Äô policies on maternity and paternity leave. Here‚Äôs what we found." False link

column1: huffingtonpost 104643218586 "2014-12-08 04:00:10 GMT" http://huffingtonpost.tumblr.com/post/104643218586/3-myths-about-female-sexuality-and-why-people "Sitting in elementary sex ed
column2: I saw an image that would stay planted in my mind for years
column3: inspiring endless curiosity and eventually leading to my sex writing career: a medical sketch of a man with an erection. When the teacher described erections as often pleasurable
column4: I was stunned. I also wondered what wacky shift in my own body would bring similar pleasure. Something good must happen to females
column6: a woman appeared on the screen! Then‚Ä¶ tampons. Maxi pads. Facts about the cramps
column7: bleeding and bloating I would experience for one-quarter of my fertile life. It seemed unfair
column8: and it was. Throughout the remainder of my sex education
column9: female sexual pleasure was never explored ‚Äì a far too common scenario.¬† On my sexuality radio show and podcast
column10: I often ask guests and listeners what they learned about sex early on. Most women tell me they either learned nothing or that sex is dirty
column11: sinful and ‚Äúslutty.‚Äù One woman told me she stopped trying to orgasm because she‚Äôd tried and ‚Äúfailed.‚Äù Lots of women don‚Äôt
column13: so what‚Äôs the big deal? We learn about sexual pleasure through experience
column14: but typically not until we‚Äôve learned myths that can hinder it. Images of sex better suited to mainstream porn are splashed about the media
column15: suggesting that we must look and act unrealistic ways to feel and appear sexy
column16: while actual porn promotes unrealistic notions of sex commonly perceived as fact. While guys think with their penises
column18: many gals would rather fake an orgasm to get sex over with or cry ‚Äúheadache!‚Äù to bypass it. When we have sex
column19: there‚Äôs a significant chance we won‚Äôt experience orgasm. That‚Äôs what many headlines suggest
column20: after all. So it must be true
column22: no. Many headlines and statistics cited throughout the media regarding female sexuality
column24: derive from myths or studies that are outdated
column25: misinterpreted or blown way out of proportion. Here are just a few common examples. For all three myths go here." True link

column1: huffingtonpost 102975791743 "2014-11-18 19:30:25 GMT" http://huffingtonpost.tumblr.com/post/102975791743/new-study-suggests-genetic-link-for-male " CHICAGO (AP) ‚Äî A large study of gay brothers adds to evidence that genes influence men‚Äôs chances of being homosexual
column2: but the results aren‚Äôt strong enough to prove it. Some scientists believe several genes might affect sexual orientation. Researchers who led the new study of nearly 800 gay brothers say their results bolster previous evidence pointing to genes on the X chromosome. They also found evidence of influence from a gene or genes on a different chromosome. But the study doesn‚Äôt identify which of hundreds of genes located in either place might be involved."
